verse: After Saul and Jonathan were killed in battle with the Philistines, David returned from defeating the Amalekites, and for two days he rested in Ziklag.
On the third day, a man came from Saulâ€™s camp in mourning, his clothes torn, dirt on his head. When he reached David, he fell to the ground facedown before him.
When David heard these words, he tore his clothing in grief; and all the men with him did the same.
They mourned and wept, and they fasted until evening in honor of Saul and Jonathan and the army of the Eternal One of Israel, because they were cut down by the sword of the enemy.
So David called for one of his soldiers to come forward and kill the Amalekite soldier, which he did.
Then David mourned the death of Saul and his son Jonathan with this song of grief,
the Song of the Bow, which he ordered taught to the people of Judah and recorded in the book of the Upright.
